1  General Information

1.3 Equipment Description

1.3.1 Section Overview

This section provides information regarding the physical equipment that is necessary for running the Wenger Automated Process Management (APM) software. Every APM controls system is delivered with a APM Human Machine Interface (HMI) control station that is intended to reside in a climate-controlled air-conditioned control room. Some customers request a second redundant station that they want located on the factory floor near the extruder system equipment. Each of these systems are described below.

1.3.2 Control Room Console

The standard Wenger APM console, or operator control station Figure 1.1 and Figure 1.2, is intended for use in an air-conditioned control room. This style of control station consists of a podium-style console, computer, monitor, keyboard, mouse, and a handful of special-purpose buttons, switches and lamps.

  1. Computer - This is a small-footprint industrial computer that usually resides inside the console cabinet (although it is occasionally mounted inside the extruder system control panel, part of which is shown in Figure 1.4 ). This computer will have some flavor of the Windows operating system installed along with Wenger HMI application software
  2. Monitor - The monitor is a standard desktop monitor that has touchscreen capability, meaning that the operator can move the mouse pointer and select screen objects by sliding and pressing his finger on the monitor.
  3. Keyboard/Mouse - The keyboard and mouse are standard USB type devices used with any typical office desktop PC. They are NOT impervious to spilled liquids.
  4. Alarm Beacon - This high-intensity lamp blinks on and off while there is one or more unacknowledged alarm conditions.
  5. Special Purpose Buttons, Switches and Lamps - shown in Figure 1.3.
  1. Manual Shutdown Rotary Switch - When rotated momentarily clockwise this switch causes the extruder system Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) to execute a normal extruder system shutdown sequence.
  2. Loss Of Communications Lamp - This lamp is illuminated by the extruder system's PLC when it fails to receive regular updated date and time information from the APM software.
  3. “Downspout Bypass” Button - This button is only pertinent when the extruder system's normal startup sequence has been completed and raw material is flowing from the preconditioner to the extruder. In this case, depressing the button causes the extruder system PLC to move the downspout from the process position to the bypass position. Releasing the button will result in the downspout returning to the process position.
  4. “Horn Silence” Button - Occasionally, certain alarm conditions cycle repeatedly between true and false, in which case the alarm horn becomes a nuisance. Pressing this button silences the alarm horn even when there are unacknowledged alarms.
  5. “Emergency Shutdown (E-Stop)” Button - This unlabeled large red mushroom button is intended for use in emergency situations. When this button is pressed, electrical power to the outputs is immediately disconnected. When pressed, the “Emergency Shutdown” button remains locked in the depressed state. To release it from its locked state it must be manually rotated, which allows it to pop back up.
  6. “E-Stop Reset” Button - Following an emergency shutdown, pressing this button reconnects electrical power to the outputs (but only after the “E-Stop” button has been manually rotated causing it to pop up).

The PLC that resides in the extruder system control panel executes software that interfaces with both the APM computer and the control panel input/output modules that read data from the extruder system equipment and write data to the same equipment. The APM computer exchanges information with the PLC via an Ethernet data link. The PLC communicates directly with an Ethernet module that resides in the same I/O module chassis in which the PLC resides (the electrical signals travel through the backplane of the I/O module chassis). This Ethernet module communicates directly with an Ethernet switch that resides in the control panel (the electrical signals travel through a connecting CAT5 Ethernet cable). This Ethernet switch communicates directly with both the Ethernet network module in the I/O module chassis (via a CAT5 Ethernet cable), and with the APM computer (via a second CAT5 Ethernet cable). The control panel components just described are shown in Figure 1.4.

  1. PLC - This executes software that both controls the extruder system equipment and communicates with the APM computer.
  2. PLC Ethernet Module - This device allows the PLC to exchange data with the APM computer through the Ethernet switch.
  3. Ethernet Switch - This device facilitates the exchange of data between the PLC and the APM computer.
  4. CAT5 Ethernet Cable - This cable (blue in the above figure) connects the PLC network module to the Ethernet switch.
  5. CAT5 Ethernet Cable - This cable (yellow in the above figure) connects the APM computer (not shown) to the Ethernet switch.

A battery backup is available for purchase for the control room control station. This optional equipment is recommended for customers who experience occasional power surges and/or losses from their local electric utility. During a power outage or other utility problems the APM computer and display monitor will receive power for a limited time from the backup battery.

  1. Battery Backup Master Outlet - This is the port that should be used for the APM computer's AC adapter.
  2. Battery Backup Outlet - This is the port that should be used for the APM monitor's AC adapter.
  3. USB Data Port - Locate the USB serial communications cable that is provided as part of the battery backup unit, mate the end of the cable with the telephone plug type of connector to this jack, and insert the other end of the cable into an external USB port of the APM computer.
  4. Input AC Power Outlet - This is the port through which the battery backup unit receives its AC power from the local utility.

1.3.3 Auxiliary Factory Floor Station

As an option, the Wenger APM can be ordered with a second (auxiliary) control station that is suitable for installation on the factory floor. This ruggedized control station is redundant with the control room station in the sense that the two monitors display the same information, and that what an operator at one station types with his keyboard or clicks with his mouse appears on the monitor of the other control.

This style HMI consists of a sealed membrane keyboard/mouse, an industrial monitor designed for use in harsh environments, an alarm beacon, and an alarm horn. All items that are part of this control station are suitable for washdown (rated NEMA 4 or IP54).

Acronyms

1  General Information

1.2 Acronyms

A list of the acronyms that appear in this document, and what they stand for, is provided in Table 1.1.

Table 1.1 Acronym Definitions
APM Automated Process Management
BPV Back Pressure Valve
DDC Differential Diameter Cylinder
HIP High Intensity Preconditioner
HMI Human Machine Interface
HOA Hand-Off-Auto
HSC High Shear Conditioner
LIW Loss In Weight
PID Proportional Integral Derivative
PLC Programmable Logic Controller
SME Specific Mechanical Energy
SMI Steam/Water Mixing Injection
